answers.answer: I have had midwives with all three of my children and LOVED them.  The office has a team of midwives, so I saw a different one at each visit and didn't always know who would actually deliver me.  Since they were all great, it didn't matter. I enjoyed getting a different persective each time.From my experience, midwives are warm, caring, and much more personable than doctors.  For example, during my second labor, which was long and difficult, two midwives spent hours in my room rubbing my back and talking to me.  What doctor is going to do that??If you do go with a doctor, I would try to find a female provider.  I just think anyone who's been through this is going to be better than someone who hasn't. = )

The choice seems obvious to me. Do you want a person who is MORE or LESS qualified to care for you? I think that ESPECIALLY in your situation, you'd want the MORE educated one - and that would be the OB. Stick with the Doctors, forget the trendy midwife. If something goes wrong, you'll be delayed waiting for a BETTER EQUIPPED doctor anyway. Midwives are NOT equipped to handle ALL situations. It seems like a no brainer to me - It's just plain smarter to go with the doctor. Good Luck in whatever you decide though.

I kind of agree with Jax. Your three biochems, combined with your age may make you higher risk. With that in mind, an OB seems like the logical choice. If you were 25, completely healthy with no previous issues, I'd say heck, go for the Midwife if you want to. But you're not...and, if it were me, I wouldn't want to risk my health or my baby's health just to have the touchy-feely personal attention of a midwife. But that's just my opinion. :-) Whatever you decide, I wish you a happy, healthy pregnancy and delivery!Tricia

I thought if you were higher risk the OB dr.s would be recommended, or even insisted.  I guess if they are giving you the choice, you may want to think of in the god forbid worst case senerio, who would you want there?  No matter what you decide...CONGRATS!!!  I am so happy for you!

especially in your case, i would go with an OB.When i had to have my c-section due to preeclampsia, i knew exactly who was doing the surgical procedure- MY doctor who had been seeing me for 9 months. He knew everything about me. I found that to be very comforting.

A midwife is fine and they are great people to deal with much more compassionate. However many delivery's are ending in c-section which will require an OB. So I would have to agree I think you should get to know an OB instead of a midwife.

Thank you all for the good advice and support!  While it took a little while to get and keep this pregnancy (I'm convinced biochems were due to low progesterone), my health is very good and no one has suggested that I would be high risk.  I think I would prefer a midwife but I'll probably go for an ob anyway just in case of any problems and then perhaps look at getting a doula for the added support during labor.  My sister had a midwife and a doula and said that the doula was amazing.

My advice is just to deliver at a hospital, not a mid wife clinic.   I am not too familiar with midwives and how and where they deliver, but my best friend is a nurse in a NICU and she sees babies come in all the time who were delivered at home with mid wives and at mid wife clinics.  Unfortunately a lot of these small problems turn into big ones and she sees a lot of the babies die.  Of course this is not all cases, but there is a reason for modern machines and hospitals.I had a wonderful nurse stay with me the entire labor and delivery, so there is nothing wrong with going the OB route.  Good luck to you!

question: Hi all.  I'm so excited to be posting here.  I'm 8w3d with my first bean, due date is Aug 21. I'm almost 40 and had 3 biochem and I don't want to talk to any of my friends or family yet (except for a few close ones) about this bc I'm nervous of m/c. So this is my question. RE just discharged me and now I have to decide on OB. My sister says I should go for a midwife instead. Is one better than the other?  I'm already checking out possible hospitals since if I go for OB, who I pick will depend on hospital affiliation. Also is there a good website for looking up the questions I should be asking on the hospital tours? Thanks all!
title: OB or Midwife?
